To describe a square on a given straight-line.

Let {AB line} be the given straight-line. So it is required to describe a square on the straight-line {AB line}.

Let {AC line} have been drawn at right-angles to the straight-line {AB line} from the point {A point} on it [Prop. 1.11], and let {AD line} have been made equal to {AB line} [Prop. 1.3].
And let {DE line} have been drawn through point {D point} parallel to {AB line} [Prop. 1.31], and let {BE line} have been drawn through point {B point} parallel to {AD line} [Prop. 1.31].
Thus, {ADEB polygon} is a parallelogram.
Thus, {AB line} is equal to {DE line}, and {AD line} to {BE line} [Prop. 1.34].
But, {AB line} is equal to {AD line}.
Thus, the four (sides) {BA line}, {AD line}, {DE line}, and {EB line} are equal to one another.
Thus, the parallelogram {ADEB polygon} is equilateral.
So I say that (it is) also right-angled.
For since the straight-line {AD line} falls across the parallel-lines {AB line} and {DE line}, the (sum of the) angles {BAD angle} and {ADE angle} is equal to two right-angles [Prop. 1.29].
But {BAD angle} (is a) right-angle.
Thus, {ADE angle} (is) also a right-angle.
And for parallelogrammic figures, the opposite sides and angles are equal to one another [Prop. 1.34].
Thus, each of the opposite angles {ABE angle} and {BED angle} (are) also right-angles.
Thus, {ADEB polygon} is right-angled.
And it was also shown (to be) equilateral.

Thus, ({ADEB polygon}) is a square [Def. 1.22]. And it is described on the straight-line {AB line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 47
prose:
In a right-angled triangle, the square on the side subtending the right-angle is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides surrounding the right-angle.

Let {ABC polygon} be a right-angled triangle having the right-angle {BAC angle}.
I say that the square on {BC line} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on {BA line} and {AC line}.

For let the square {BDEC polygon} have been described on {BC line}, and (the squares) {GB polygon} and {HC polygon} on {AB line} and {AC line} (respectively) [Prop. 1.46].
And let {AL line} have been drawn through point {A point} parallel to either of {BD line} or {CE line} [Prop. 1.31].
And let {AD line} and {FC line} have been joined.
And since angles {BAC angle} and {BAG angle} are each right-angles, then two straight-lines {AC line} and {AG line}, not lying on the same side, make the (sum of the) adjacent angles equal to two right-angles at the same point {A point} on some straight-line {BA line}.
Thus, {CA line} is straight-on to {AG line} [Prop. 1.14].
So, for the same (reasons), {BA line} is also straight-on to {AH line}.
And since angle {DBC angle} is equal to {FBA angle}, for (they are) both right-angles, let {ABC angle} have been added to both.
Thus, the whole (angle) {DBA angle} is equal to the whole (angle) {FBC angle}.
And since {DB line} is equal to {BC line}, and {FB line} to {BA line}, the two (straight-lines) {DB line}, {BA line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {CB line}, {BF line}, respectively.
And angle {DBA angle} (is) equal to angle {FBC angle}.
Thus, the base {AD line} [is] equal to the base {FC line}, and the triangle {ABD polygon} is equal to the triangle {FBC polygon} [Prop. 1.4].
And parallelogram {BL polygon} [is] double (the area) of triangle {ABD polygon}.
For they have the same base, {BD line}, and are between the same parallels, {BD line} and {AL line} [Prop. 1.41].
And square {GB polygon} is double (the area) of triangle {FBC polygon}.
For again they have the same base, {FB line}, and are between the same parallels, {FB line} and {GC line} [Prop. 1.41].
[And the doubles of equal things are equal to one another.]
Thus, the parallelogram {BL polygon} is also equal to the square {GB polygon}.
So, similarly, {AE line} and {BK line} being joined, the parallelogram {CL polygon} can be shown (to be) equal to the square {HC polygon}.
Thus, the whole square {BDEC polygon} is equal to the (sum of the) two squares {GB polygon} and {HC polygon}.
And the square {BDEC polygon} is described on {BC line}, and the (squares) {GB polygon} and {HC polygon} on {BA line} and {AC line} (respectively).
Thus, the square on the side {BC line} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides {BA line} and {AC line}.

Thus, in a right-angled triangle, the square on the side subtending the right-angle is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides surrounding the right-[angle].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 48
prose:
If the square on one of the sides of a triangle is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the remaining sides of the triangle then the angle contained by the remaining sides of the triangle is a right-angle.

For let the square on one of the sides, {BC line}, of triangle {ABC polygon} be equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides {BA line} and {AC line}.
I say that angle {BAC angle} is a right-angle.

For let {AD line} have been drawn from point {A point} at right-angles to the straight-line {AC line} [Prop. 1.11], and let {AD line} have been made equal to {BA line} [Prop. 1.3], and let {DC line} have been joined.
Since {DA line} is equal to {AB line}, the square on {DA line} is thus also equal to the square on {AB line}.
Let the square on {AC line} have been added to both.
Thus, the (sum of the) squares on {DA line} and {AC line} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on {BA line} and {AC line}.
But, the (sum of the squares) on {DA line} and {AC line} is equal to the (square) on {DC line}.
For angle {DAC angle} is a right-angle [Prop. 1.47].
But, the (sum of the squares) on {BA line} and {AC line} is equal to the (square) on {BC line}.
For (that) was assumed.
Thus, the square on {DC line} is equal to the square on {BC line}.
So {DC line} is also equal to {BC line}.
And since {DA line} is equal to {AB line}, and {AC line} (is) common, the two (straight-lines) {DA line}, {AC line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {BA line}, {AC line}.
And the base {DC line} is equal to the base {BC line}.
Thus, angle {DAC angle} [is] equal to angle {BAC angle} [Prop. 1.8].
But {DAC angle} is a right-angle.
Thus, {BAC angle} is also a right-angle.

Thus, if the square on one of the sides of a triangle is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the remaining sides of the triangle then the angle contained by the remaining sides of the triangle is a right-angle.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.
